children.name: explain a2
children.definition: explain to give sb the information they need to understand sth:giải thích
examples: it’s not so complicated - let me explain.
we listened carefully while pam explained the process.
let me show you - it’s too difficult to explain.
explain sth to sb
if you don’t get the joke, i’ll explain it to you later.
could you explain the rules of the game to me, please?
explain how/ what/ why etc
can you explain what the poem means?
the doctor explained how the clinic operates.

children.name: tell a1
children.definition: tell especiallyspokento explain to sb how sth works or how to do sth:nói , chỉ
examples: tell sb how/ what/ why etc
can you tell me how to log on to the internet?
the leaflet tells you what to do if you get malaria.

children.name: show b1
children.definition: show to explain to sb how to do sth by doing itwhile they watch you:chỉ cho ai cách làm gì
examples: ‘how do you change the speed of the drill?’ ‘let me show you.’
show sb sth
i’ll show you an easier way to get down from there.
show sb how to do sth
can you show me how to use your camera?
show sb what to do
if you show him what to do, i’m sure he’ll do a good job.

children.name: demonstrate c1
children.definition: demonstrate to showsb how to do sth bydoing it while they watch you, especiallywhen it is your jobto show people how to do things:giải thích
examples: the ski instructor began by demonstrating the correct way to turn.
if you still don’t understand, marcia will be happy to demonstrate.
demonstrate how
a trainer came in to demonstrate how the new computer system worked.

children.name: go through x
children.definition: go through sth to explain all thedetailsabout sth in therightorder, to help sb understand it:
examples: i’ll go through the instructions once more in case you missed anything.
if you stay after class, i’ll go through the theory with you again.

children.name: say why a1
children.definition: say what/ why/ where etc spoken to explain the reasons for sth or give detailed information about sth:
examples: he didn’t say where he was going or who he was going with.
did caroline say why she needed the tape recorder?

children.name: throw light on c2
children.definition: throw/shed light on written to provide new information which makes sth easier to understand, especially sth which has been studied, but which is still not well understood:làm sáng tỏ
examples: these discoveries may shed light on the origins of the universe.
scientists working in the gobi desert have thrown new light on the life of dinosaurs.

children.name: set out b2
children.definition: set out to explain facts, arguments, reasons etc by stating them clearly and in a carefully planned order:trình bày
examples: set out sth/ set sth out
she set out the reasons for her resignation in a confidential letter to her boss.
the republicans’ goals for the year are clearly set out in the party platform.
the facts, as you have set them out, seem convincing enough.

children.name: spoken: when you are going to explain
see
children.definition: (you) spoken say this when you are explaining sth to sb, and you want to check that they are listening and that they understand you: thấy chưa
examples: ▪ this fits on here, see, where the arrow is.
▪ simon’s car broke down, you see, and neither of us knew how to fix it.

children.name: i mean
children.definition: /aɪ ˈmiːn/spokensay this when you are explaining something you have said or giving an example of something:
examples: ý tôi là
▪ ted seems kind of lazy. i mean, he never offers to help and he just lies in front of the tv.
ted trông khá lười biếng. ý tôi là, anh ta không bao giờ đề nghị giúp đỡ và chỉ nằm trước tivi.
what i mean (to say) is
ý tôi muốn nói là
▪ i’m afraid i can’t help you. what i mean is that i’m not a detective, and i don’t solve crimes.
tôi e là không giúp bạn được. ý tôi muốn nói là tôi không phải thám tử, và tôi không phá án.

children.name: in other words
children.definition: /ɪn ˌʌðəʳ ˈwɜːʳdz/ use this when you are saying something in a different way in order to explain it more clearly:
examples: nói cách khác
▪ what we need is a more sustainable transport system, in other words, more buses and trains, and fewer cars.
cái chúng ta cần là một hệ thống vận chuyển bền vững, nói cách khác, nhiều xe buýt và tàu hỏa, ít xe ô tô đi.
▪ this is supposed to be a democracy - in other words, one person one vote.
đây nên là một nền dân chủ- nói cách khác, mỗi người một phiếu.

children.name: that is
children.definition: /ˈðæt ɪz/ use this to explain the meaning of the previous word or phrase by giving more information about it: đó là
examples: ▪ the fare is reduced for children, that is, anyone under 15 years old.
giá vé được giảm cho trẻ em, đó là, những bé dưới 15 tuổi.
▪ all documents are printed in the two official languages - that is, english and french.
mọi tài liệu đều được in ra hai ngôn ngữ, đó là tiếng anh và tiếng pháp.

children.name: let me explain
children.definition: /ˌlet miː ɪkˈspleɪn/spokensay this when you want to explain something to someone because you think they have not understood:
examples: để tôi giải thích
▪ i can see you’re getting confused. let me explain.
tôi thấy được bạn đang bối rối. để tôi giải thích.
▪ i know the plan seems a little crazy at first, but it’s really not. let me explain.
tôi biết kế hoạch thoạt đầu nghe có vẻ điên rồ, nhưng không phải đâu. để tôi giải thích.

children.name: the thing is
children.definition: /ðə ˈθɪŋ ɪz/ spoken use this when you are explaining a problem or the reason for something:
examples: vấn đề ở đây là
▪ i really don’t want to leave yet. the thing is, i have an appointment in 15 minutes.
tôi thật sự chưa muốn đi. nhưng vấn đề là, tôi có hẹn trong 15 phút nữa.
▪ i do have a computer, but the thing is, it’s really old and i can’t use it for email.
tôi có máy tính, nhưng vấn đề là, nó đã quá cũ rồi và tôi không thể dùng nó để gửi mail.

children.name: to put it another way
children.definition: /tə ˌpʊt ɪt əˈnʌðəʳ ˌweɪ/ used when you have explained something in one way and you are going to try to make it clearer by explaining it in a different way:
examples: hay nói cách khác
▪ money makes money. to put it another way, the more you invest, the greater your potential profit will be.
tiền đẻ ra tiền. hay nói cách khác, bạn đầu tư càng nhiều, lợi nhuận tiềm năng càng cao.
▪ the problem demands a global solution. to put it another way, local regulations will have very little effect.
vấn đề này cần một giải pháp mang toàn cầu. hay nói cách khác, các chính sách địa phương có rất ít ảnh hưởng.

children.name: put it like this
children.definition: / put it this way/ˌpʊt ɪt laɪk ˈðɪs, ˌpʊt ɪt ˈðɪs weɪ/ spoken say this when someone is not sure what you mean and you are going to try to explain in a way that will help them to understand, especially by saying something humorous or direct:
examples: nói thế này
▪ ‘does he get many dates?’ ‘put it like this - you don’t have to feel sorry for him.’
'anh ấy còn nhiều thời gian chứ?' 'nói cách này- bạn không cần cảm thấy tiếc cho anh ấy.'
▪ put it this way, honey - what the boss doesn’t know isn’t going to bother him.
nói thế này, em à- điều ông sếp không biết sẽ không ảnh hưởng gì đế ông ta hết.

children.name: let me rephrase that
children.definition: /ˌlet miː riːˈfreɪz ðæt/ spoken used when you are going to use different words to say something again, because you have just said it in an unsuitable way and it may not have been understood correctly:
examples: để tôi nói lại
▪ i’m sorry, let me rephrase that. that wasn’t what i meant to say at all.
xin lỗi, để tôi nói lại. đó không phải ý tôi muốn nói.
▪ most of the people there were incredibly old. let me rephrase that - we were the youngest couple there.
nhiều người ở đó lớn tuổi đến kinh ngạc. để tôi nói lại, chúng ta là cặp trẻ nhất ở đấy.

children.name: make clear a2
children.definition: make clear/ make it clearlàm rõ
examples: i tried to make clear exactly what i meant.
make it clear (that)
the teacher made it clear that she would not allow talking in class.
make something clear
we want to make the rules clear from the beginning.
make yourself clearmake it clear what you mean
am i making myself clear?

children.name: clarify c1
children.definition: clarify formal to make sth clearer, especially because people have not completely understood it: làm sáng tỏ, dễ hiểu
examples: i hope this statement has helped to clarify a few points.
could you clarify the first point please? i don't understand it completely.
clarify your positionmake it clear what you think about sth and what your intentions are
the senator tried to clarify his position on abortion.
thepositionof all shareholders will be clarified next month when we finalize our proposals.
clarification[u] c1
parts of the document are ambiguous and in need of clarification.

children.name: spell out x
children.definition: spell out to explain sth in the clearest possible way, especially when you think it should be unnecessary to make things so simple or to give so many details: giải thích rõ ràng
examples: do i have to spell out to you how important this is to me?
andrews was asked to spell out exactly how pensions would be affected.
campbell spelled out the reasons why staff reductions were necessary.
the government has so far refused to spell out its plans/policies.
informalwhat do you mean you don't understand - do i have to spell it out for you?

children.name: lay it on the line x
children.definition: lay it on the line informal to state sth clearly and strongly, especially sth that other people may be unwilling to listen to or accept:
examples: i’m going to lay it on the line. if you don’t quit drinking, i’m going to leave you.

children.name: to explain sth in a simpler way
simplify c1
children.definition: simplify to explain sth difficult in simple language so that it is easier to understand:đơn giản hóa. làm cho dễ hiểu, rút gọn
examples: we have done everything we can to simplify the procedure.
she took a complex topic and simplified it in a way that we could all understand.

children.name: demystify x
children.definition: demystify to give a simple, clear explanation of an important but difficult subject so that it is easier for ordinary people to understand:làm rõ
examples: this new book demystifies some of the computer language currently in use.
the course seeks to demystify the loan application process for people buying a home for the first time.

children.name: in plain english x
children.definition: in plain english if you explain sth or tell sb sth in plain english, you explain it simply and clearly, without using difficult words or technical language:nói đơn giản
examples: i just wish someone would explain to me in plain english what is wrong with my computer.
it says ‘the children lack the ability to mobilize self and commit’ - what does that mean in plain english?

children.name: to tell sb the reason for sth
explain away x
children.definition: explain away to tell sb the reason why you did sth or why sth happened, with the intention of making them think you have not done anything wrong or bad:thanh minh, biện hộ
examples: george was trying to explain away his outburst, saying that he’d been under a lot of pressure.
the government tried to explain away the police’s unexpected brutality, but this only led to rioting.
but there’s broken glass all over the floor - how are we going to explain that away?

children.name: give a reason a2
children.definition: give a reason to tell sb why you are doing sth, especially sth surprising:nói lí do
examples: ‘he says he’s not coming.’ ‘oh, did he give a reason?’
give sb a reason
the landlord told us we had to go, but we were never given any reason.

children.name: say why a1
children.definition: say why/ tell sb why to tell sb why sth happened:nói ai đó tại sao
examples: i knew she was annoyed, but she wouldn’t say why.
can anyone tell us why there are no buses today?

children.name: explain a2
children.definition: explain to tell sb the reason for sth, so that they understand the situation better:giải thích
examples: she just doesn’t like me. how else can you explain her behaviour?
i don’t have time to explain now - just come with me quickly!
explain why/how/what etc
doctors are unable to explain why the disease spread so quickly.
explain that
sarah explained that she hadn’t been feeling well recently.
explain to
it was difficult explaining to the children why their father was leaving home.

children.name: account for c2
children.definition: account forsth to tell sb the reason for sth that has happened, especially when people are looking for a reason to explain it:giải thích cho
examples: if you walked home, how do you account for the fact that a witness said he saw you driving your van?
it is difficult to account for the big differences in their scores.

children.name: provide an explanation b1
children.definition: provide an explanation/ come up with an explanation to tell sb the reason why sth happened when they have asked you to explain.provide an explanationis more formal thancome up with an explanation: :đưa ra lời giải thích
examples: in an attempt to provide an explanation she said she thought i had given her permission to be absent.
after failing to come up with an adequate explanation, jones was arrested for robbery.

children.name: justify b2
children.definition: justify to tell sb why sth that seems wrong is in fact right:bào chữa, biện hộ, lý giải
examples: how can you justify the expense?
are you sure that these measures are justified?
justify doing sth
how can you possibly justify charging four pounds for a glass of beer?
i can't really justify takinganother day off work.
justifyyourselfif you justify yourself, you give a good reason for what you have done
it was the only thing that i could do-i don't have to justify myselftoanyone.

children.name: convey c1
children.definition: conveyverbcommunicate
examples: to express a thought, feeling or idea so that it is understood by other people
_his poetry conveys a great sense of religious devotion.
_if you see james, do convey my apologies (tohim).
_[ + question word ]i tried to convey in my speechhowgrateful we all were for his help.
_you don't want to convey the impressionthatwe're not interested.

children.name: illustrate c1
children.definition: illustrateverbexplainminh hoạ
examples: to show the meaning or truth of something more clearly, especially by giving examples
_the lecturer illustrated his pointwitha diagram on the blackboard.
_this latest conflict further illustrates the weakness of the un.
_[ + question word ]the exhibition will illustratehowlife evolved from water.

children.name: the sound of sth c2
children.definition: the sound ofsth
examples: how something seems to be, from what is said or written
_i like the sound of the beef in red wine sauce.
_by/fromthe sound ofiti don't think it was her fault.
_so i'm going to be talking to over ninety people, am i? i don't like the sound of that!

children.name: argue b2
children.definition: argueverbgive reasonsbiện luận
examples: [ i or t ] to give the reasons for your opinion, idea, belief, etc.
_the minister arguedfor/in favour of/againstmaking cuts in military spending.
_[ + that ]the minister arguedthatcuts in military spending were needed.
_you can argue thecaseeither way.
